reviewText: Sweden already filmed these mysteries and did well, but for those who don't like subtitles and to widen the audience in the English speaking world, the BBC remade the Wallander mysteries and did very well. Each of the mysteries is complexly plotted and easy to follow the many twists and turns. Kenneth Branagh is amazing as the conflicted, depressed Wallander who verges on the brink of instability and insubordination but whose obsession to solve the crime carries him through exhaustion and personal difficulties.I have not yet read the books, so cannot comment on the adaptation but the writing is very good for the main characters and for the guest stars. The supporting cast is a bit bland. The actors do their best but the writing gives them no personality or individuality, with the exception of the pathologist who is recognizable because he is always standing near the murder victim. This small complaint aside, the Wallander mysteries are a great watch for fans of Masterpiece Mystery or the original series of books. I devoured them over the course of a week and kept wishing for more.

reviewText: For those of you who need light, happy and uplifting endings then obviously Wallander is not for you but the reason it works for me is because it's real and it's gritty.  Wallander is some of the best work that Branagh has done in a very long time.  Wallander is weary, he's hardened and he's vulnerable.  He sees the worst in certain people and I love that about him.  There is true evil out in the world and Wallander has seen it.  This is a really good series and a bit different being set in Sweden.  We have never really seen such a dark series set in this beautiful country so it's a nice change of pace.  If you like your crime dramas gritty and dark with some great acting from the main character then Wallander is something you'll enjoy.

reviewText: It must be the cold northern climes that bring out the chilling, gory, sadistic murders that face Kurt Wallander.  He's the perfect Raymond Chandleresque detective to solve them: logical, diligent, cool, devoted to his job but at what a cost-- distant, complex personal relationships and occasional mayhem visited upon his fellow cops, ex-cops, and friends.  In his dogged striving to find the truth, Wallander must pay the price of being a loner-- just watch him move singly through the bleak, stark Swedish landscape.

reviewText: I was slow to catch up on this series- I think I watched a couple of episodes on PBS when first broadcast, then kind of drifted away. Now that I have the whole series, I have watched each episode back to back and see a trajectory for this character that is fascinating.The writing of each story is slightly different, though each is based on the novels; and each murder has a hook. Sometimes very graphic, but not exploitive. It serves the story when graphic scenes are used. The stories are much more about the man Kurt Wallander and how he lives. Music, photography and character work of Ken Branaugh are all fantastic and absorbing. I hope there is another season of Wallander coming.

reviewText: I am a big fan of British television, especially comedy and detective programs. Something about them is more appealing than most US television these days.Anyway, I stumbled upon the Wallander series by accident one day and watched the first episode. I was hooked.The series is based on novels written by a Swedish author which are set in Sweden. There was a Swedish video version and then a British TV version was made later. The British version, reviewed here, is done with UK actors and filmed in Sweden.I think that Wallander is darker and more violent than most British detective programs that I've seen. Graphic at times, but not overdone as in much American television. Just enough to shock a little and keep the viewer's attention riveted.These episodes are the second season.In "Faceless Killers", an elderly couple are murdered in their farmhouse for no apparent reason. It gets out that foreigners may be the killers. Apparently, there are some extreme right wing anti-immigrant groups in Sweden, and they get involved. Very shocking conclusion here."The Man Who Smiled" involves murder and a big charity. The first murder is a very scary sequence. Lots of twists and turns. Rupert Graves plays the head of the charity. Beware of men who smile - all is not as it seems.In "The Fifth Woman", a bird watcher, a florist and a jogger are killed in bizarre ways. Wallander seems to find a girl friend along the way. "Hell hath no fury like a woman scorned" might apply here - well sort of I guess.Highly recommended. Available on Netflix streaming. This is the second of three or four seasons of the series.

reviewText: Well, we are back to visit with Kurt Wallander and his ever present family problems overshadowed,of course, by the crimes that pull at him and cause him personal distress. We are back in Sweden,walking with Wallander who is sometimes more important to the plot than the crime. There is nodoubt these are character driven mysteries and Kenneth Branagh is again up to the task brilliantly.The first episode of three, "Faceless Killers", investigates the slaying of an elderly couple at aremote farmhouse. A leak from the police about the wife's dying words sparks racist violence andall the fallout has Wallander doubting his abilities as a police officer. During the investigation he isaccused by his daughter of being a racist.The second entry of the series, "The Man Who Smiled", has an old friend of  Kurt Wallander's highlysuspicious that his father has been murdered. At first Wallander refuses to get involved because hehas been suspended from the force, but as events pile up he is convinced to take a closer look atthe case. It is a corker. There is an international conspiracy afoot that can threaten countlessinnocent lives.The third and last of Series Two is "The Fifth Woman". This is another of those cases that seem tobe unconnected but Wallander feels there is a connection. A bird-watcher falls to his death in whatappears to be a well planned murder. The seemingly unconnected case of a local man disappearingis getting Wallander increasingly suspicious that he may be looking for a serial killer bent uponrevenge.Wallander also gets too close to one of the suspects (this is Wallander's weakness and strength aswell) which can serve him as well as undermine his investigation. Wallander must also deal with hisdying father as the killings progress. Yes, family still intervenes into his life as it can for most of us.This series, like the last one, is intelligent and thoughtful. I was pulled along as if I were on thetrail with Wallander.  The photography is splendid as usual, again with bluish overtones that seemsto cast a pall over Wallander's proceedings. The series is maturing as the production crew  and castcontinue to explore the Wallander series.This Series deserves a 5 Star rating for its high production values, photography, writing and acting.Terrific stuff for all you mystery fans out there.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------NOTE: At the time of this review you are able to stream this series Free if you are an AmazonPrime member. Have at it for goodness sake.
summary: Wonderful Series 2:  'Wallander' Continues | Faceless Killers | The Man Who Smiled | The Fifth Woman
Title: N/A

reviewText: BBC has produced a second set of excellent film adaptations of Henning Mankell's Kurt Wallander detective novels, returning most of the original cast, including Kenneth Branagh, who absolutely inhabits Mankell's moody Swedish detective on screen.  Like the first series, these three films are set on location in and around the southern coastal city of Ystad. The evocative Swedish landscape helps set the tone of the films.In "Faceless Killers", an elderly couple are slaughtered in their own home.  Foreigners are suspected, and Wallander ends up in a race against time to find and stop the real killers before Ystad explodes in hate crimes.  Wallander himself ends up being a casualty of the violence.In "The Man Who Smiled", Wallander, out on extended sick leave, is approached by an old acquaitance, who asks him to check into the mysterious death of his elderly father.  Wallander discovers a trail of clues that lead back to a wealthy philanthropist and another burnt-out policeman.  Wallander will have to argue his way back on duty to solve a difficult case.In "The Fifth Woman", a series of vicious revenge killings have the Ystad police scratching their heads.  Only Wallander has the intuitive insight and dogged determination to connect the cases and capture a mysterious and ruthless killer.The "Wallander" mysteries are not for everyone.  Wallander himself is unable to remained detached from his work; his personal life is a painful emotional trainwreck.  The stories are quite dark; those who need clean happy endings are likely to be disapppointed.  Fans of the novels should expect that complex plots have been simplified for the screen.  That said, "Wallander" Set Two is highly recommended to fans of the series.  This DVD set includes a couple of background features on the production of the series.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Too bad a good cast and good production values are wasted in this poor translation of three Henning Mankell novels from the Kurt Wallander series to the screen.  Certainly they manage to establish a bleak atmosphere, but there is virtually nothing in the way of character development or pace.  "The Fifth Woman," it seems to me, suffers the most from being squeezed into a 90-minute format, but it did none of the plots any good.  There are way too many shots of Wallander's Volvo zooming up and down the road, and not enough about the man himself--Branagh plays Wallander very opaquely, with very little texture.  There's very little to interest us in him.Obviously, when a novel is being made into a film, changes have to be made, and some not-so-great novels have been turned into first-class entertainments.  It seems a shame that with all that is available in the Wallander books, so little has been made of them here.Enjoyable only if you're stuck at home with the flu.  Read and enjoy the novels.

reviewText: The first series of Wallander filmswon the annual British award for Best Drama Series, and the BBC followed up in January 2010 with a second series of three movies:  "Faceless Killers," "The Man Who Smiled," and "The Fifth Woman."Kenneth Branagh once again plays Kurt Wallander, a fortysomething detective in Ystad, Sweden.  The murders that Wallander is called upon to solve not only involve disputes between individuals but also touch on some of the fissures in current Swedish society.  Through it all, Wallander must also deal with career-related stress, health problems including diabetes, and strained family relations.Just as in the first series, Ystad and the surrounding countryside provide a striking background to the films, and one of the bonus features on this DVD set looks at both indoor and outdoor settings used.  This set contains another bonus feature with insights into the Wallander character.If you enjoyed the first set of Wallander films, you'll like these as well.  I see that the BBC is airing a third set of films in April, and I eagerly await its release on DVD.

reviewText: If you have been captivated by the first installment of "Wallander" episodes, the second is a must for you. If, on the other hand, you find Wallander and his world too bleak (I disagree with respect, but this is a matter of taste), you are well advised to pass up the second set. Regardless whether you have read Henning Mankell's Wallander novels - great literature in the disguise of great detective fiction - or not, the film scripts can stand on their own merits, as the plots are, to the most part, intelligently curtailed and extracted from the books. The cast of characters is excellent, the films, beautifully shot against the colorful backdrop of the Swedish country- and cityside, focus not only on the whodunit with its police procedural, but tackle very real social issues and problems present in all western societies. While Kenneth Branagh certainly would not have been my imaginary "ideal" Wallander persona when I read the novels, I find him an almost perfect choice for the role. His mostly dysfunctional private life, very well captured, mirrors the world of crime in an often dysfunctional society. Whether the camera actually assumes his subjective viewpoint or not, all events appear to be seen through his eyes: with compassion, helpless anger and complex, brooding introspection. The three films in this set are as suspenseful as they are thought provoking. You will want to watch them again. Highly recommended. A tip for those who own an all-zone DVD player: check the prices of the Wallander sets on amazon.co.uk.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This TV series, as with the books they're based on, will not be everybody's cup of tea. They are unrelentingly dour and humorless. They are well plotted and fabulously acted, but even the cinematography seems to have a blue cast that adds to the bleakness. Kenneth Branagh is magnificent throughout. What an actor!I've only read two Kurt Wallander mysteries, written by Henning Mankell and set in Skane, Southern Sweden. The two I've read are "Faceless Killers" (published 1991 in Sweden), the first in the series, and "The Troubled Man" (published 2009 in Sweden), the last in the series. Kurt is a police detective. He's a good detective, though he's so intense and focused that he can be hard on witnesses, his co-workers, his family, and most of all, on himself.This is the 2nd season of Kenneth Branagh's "Wallender", which originally aired in 2010: episodes "Faceless Killers", "The Man Who Smiled" and "The Fifth Woman". The 1st season is also available on DVD, which originally aired in 2008: episodes "Sidetracked", "Firewall" and "One Step Behind". All of the screenplays, for both sets, are based on Mankell's books by the same names.I think both TV series do an excellent job of capturing the books' Wallander. He is moderately unkempt; recently divorced but still wearing his wedding ring. He works horrific hours and has trouble sleeping at night on top of it. He sees society's underbelly on a daily basis and it has left his emotions alternately strangled and unavailable or else spewing volcanically. His relationship with his daughter is actually better in the TV series than in the books. And he is more nominally likeable in the TV series than he is in the two books I've read.There are currently plans for a 3rd TV series, and screenwriters have been commissioned. Apparently, three of the episodes will be original screenplays, not based on a Wallander book. If the series keeps going, they'll have to do so. Mankell has only written 13 Wallander novels (one, a prequel, is set pre-"Faceless Killers").I very much enjoyed watching this series, and the 1st series, too. A purist may not appreciate a Swedish series filmed in Skane, but populated 100% by English speaking characters, but it was OK with me. Kenneth Branagh appeared at a 2009 interview in NYC, and was asked if he had considered performing Wallander with a Swedish accent. Branagh replied: "Oh yes! But literally a moment. I sounded like the Swedish chef from the Muppets." And the idea was quickly dropped.
summary: Dour and Realistic - with Fabulous Acting

reviewText: WALLANDER is a detective mystery.  Inspector Kurt Wallander and his staff are busy finding the criminal within Ystad, a town in Southern Sweden.This movie becomes fascinating as the viewer learns bits & pieces of what motivates Kurt to hunt down the evildoer.Also as captivating is how Inspector Wallander interfaces with his staff and female boss. Altho Kurt relies on their help, he also has to train & lead his staff about proper police procedures.The most appealing aspect of this series is to observe how Kurt has to sift thru the clues & distractions left at the crime scene by the murderer. The twists & turns require that the viewer is settled snuggly in his chair during this adventurous ride thru various investigations of a handful of suspects.  But eventually a prime suspect surfaces above the landscape of evidence, so that a chase and catch can commence.Altho each case is solved, the viewer is just as exhausted as Kenneth Branagh (Kurt), because we have put just as much of our own character in this hunt.  Solving these mysteries is thrilling, because it is a full workout of both the mind & emotions.Jo Jo.

reviewText: This is feature film television, with the pacing, performances and production values you'd expect of a film.  Brannaugh is simply superb, with a supporting cast on equal par.  The true stars here however, are writer and director, at the top of their game.  These are dark, dystopic descents into the dark side of human nature, with rewarding moments of discovery and levity peppered throughout.  beautifully lensed in Sweden, and meticulously crafted for eerie, haunting and utterly human impact, if you appreciate a great mystery and storytelling at its pinnacle, you could not invest your time better.

reviewText: This is a wonderful series of full movie length, sombre murder mysteries.  Set in Sweden, the stark and lovely landscape adds character to the storylines, which wind out slowly and without a distracting, crashing soundtrack.  Instead, the characters tell the story and the backdrop creates the mood.  Sometimes a little gritty, which my husband handles better than I do; sometimes fused with political and/or social issues of our day, which I'd rather not see in entertainment.  Hence the four stars instead of five.  But all sides are presented well, which I feel is unusual for modern drama.  The actors are well-chosen, and Kenneth Branagh, as always, just fills the screen.  Brilliantly done.

reviewerName: Michael B. Druxman "A Good Story is a Terribl...
reviewText: WALLANDER is, by far, the best cop/mystery series that I have come across in many years.  Indeed, it avoids almost all of the flaws that seem to plague even the most popular television shows of that genre.Perhaps that's because the stories are adapted directly from Henning Mankell's novels, rather than being ground out by a television writer fighting a deadline.Kurt Wallander (Kenneth Branagh) is an overworked Swedish police detective in the small, backwater town of Ystad.  He is divorced from his wife, his artist father (David Warner) is in the early stages of Alzheimer's disease and Wallander himself suffers from diabetes.  Aside from his work, the only meaningful relationship that he has in his life is with his grown daughter, which runs hot-and-cold.Like with most mystery writers, Mankell's stories have a formula, but his is a formula that is not easy to second- guess.  In each of these three new movies, Wallander is confronted with initially seemingly unrelated crimes, which as the investigations proceed, actually turn out to be tied together.In FACELESS KILLERS, for example, the murder of an elderly couple in their farmhouse results in an outbreak of racial violence.In THE MAN WHO SMILED, the detective is asked by an old friend to investigate the mysterious death of his father, then a week later, the friend turns up dead.THE FIFTH WOMAN opens with the brutal murder of an elderly birdwatcher, the first of many of a clever serial killer.Wearing a three-day beard, Branagh delivers a superb portrayal of the emotionally distressed detective.  The supporting casts, none of which (with the exception of David Warner) are familiar to this writer, are also fine.The three movies for this second season are well-paced and play more like good theatrical films, rather than something made to be seen on television.The 2-disc set from BBC Video contains a pair of "Behind the Scenes" featurettes. Michael B. Druxman
Title: N/A

reviewText: I enjoyed Wallander Series 2 more than the first series, as at least some of the mysteries do not defy all credibility. Based on the Swedish crime novels of Henning Mankel, this trio of mysteries grows more sensational as it progresses, but the unbelievable bits creep up on the viewer instead of being outright off-the-wall. As is often the case, Mankel has entwined social issues with his murders: anti-immigration sentiment, trafficking in human organs, and domestic abuse. Dave Shiflett of Bloomberg aptly described Kurt Wallander as "perhaps the most melancholy man on television" and Kenneth Branagh's performance as "majestically morose". He is an unlikely police officer. Wallander has a strong sense of justice but a hard time coping with life in general, much less with the brutality with which he job brings him into constant contact. He's never in a stable state of mind.The Wallander series is also set apart from most television cop dramas by Wallander's lack of relationship with his colleagues. Fellow detectives Anne-Brit Hoglund (Sarah Smart), Magnus Martinsson (Tom Hiddleston), and pathologist Nyberg (Richard McCabe) are always there, making helpful contributions, but Wallander has no personal relationship with them and barely a professional one. They're just part of the landscape. This is more in the mold of noir fiction, which focuses on the protagonist's angst and how he is acted upon by the world around him. But Wallander's crises are emotional, not existential. He processes everything on an emotional level, to the extent that he seems always to fail his needy daughter and father, the people with whom he is most preoccupied. There are three 90-minute episodes:An elderly couple are murdered in their farmhouse by someone apparently looking  for hidden money in "Faceless Killers". Wallander thinks the dying woman may have whispered "foreigner" -or was it "farmer"? He couldn't make it out, but the "foreigner" angle is leaked to the press and inspires vigilante action against a local community of migrant workers. Wallander thinks things will settle down if he finds the couple's killers. He and partner Hoglund (Sarah Smart) hope to uncover some clues in the victim's former mistress and illegitimate son. Meanwhile, Wallander must cope with his father's deteriorating condition and his daughter's new boyfriend. This mystery is especially good, because it is not overwrought, and the culprits commit plausible crimes with plausible motives."The Man Who Smiled" finds Wallander on leave and planning to resign following the events of the previous episode. An old friend, Sten Torstensson (David Sibley) asks Wallander to look into the odd circumstances surrounding the recent death of his father Gustave in an auto accident. But, by the time Wallander gets around to it, Sten is himself dead, supposedly a suicide. Wallander feels guilty and begs to go back to work, but he has become dependent on tranquilizers and struggles with withdrawal. And his colleague Magnus (Tom Hiddleston) resents Wallander's intrusion into the case. The Torstenssons were solicitors to a wealthy philanthropist named Alfred Harderberg (Rupert Graves), who received a similar death threat, so the detectives begin there inquiry there.An elderly birdwatcher is found gruesomely murdered in "The Fifth Woman", the first in a series of torture-murders that have no obvious connection. When a missing florist is found murdered, then a late-night jogger, it becomes clear that Wallander and his colleagues are dealing with a serial killer who targets financially successful men with a history of bullying women. But that leaves a long list of potential suspects and difficulty in determining who might be the next victim. Wallander, meanwhile, is becoming fond of the second victim's forlorn business manager, Vanja Andersson (Saskia Reeves), a potential suspect, while he deals with the usual family dramas that leave him barely fit for work. This is the most sensational of the episodes, and its social agenda seems overstated.
summary: Branagh Gives Strong Performance in These Dark, Emotive Swedish Mysteries.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The other "2 Star" reviews here are correct so I'll say a few things they don't.  First, Branagh is the only actor worth watching.  The rest are cardboard cutouts.  Second, the mysteries really aren't the focus of the plots, instead the story lines involve everyone else giving Wallander crap about details of his personal life, professionalism, etc. and he just lamely takes it.  If it is faithful to the novels, fine, but all episodes feature (a) someone dies, (b) Wallander shows up clueless, (c) Wallander takes crap about his personal life or professionalism, (d) Wallander seems to investigate further as an "escape" more than anything else, (e) Wallander takes more crap, and (e) through an accident or two the perpetrator practically gives him/herself up.  Third, this series doesn't stand for anything.  That is, there is no real projection of good or goodness, just bad (typically the evil white man) and people piddling their time away in depressing diversions.  In toto, I find myself wishing that every single character we see just dies.  Including Wallander, to put himself out of his dawdling misery.

reviewText: I have never been so glad as to have an Amazon Prime membership as when I got to sample this series. I had seen the promotions for it on my Sherlock DVD and that was enough to make me curious. However, I probably would not have taken a chance on this show because cop dramas (even ones with superb actors) have gotten very predictable. Because of my Prime membership, I was able to watch this on my Kindle Fire and I was blown away. These scripts are incredibly well written and the acting in it brings the stories to life in a way that you do not often get to see. I swallowed the first season in two days and had to force myself to pace out the second season better, as there are only three years of it so far. If crime dramas are your 'thing', then this is an absolute treat and I recommend it with the highest of accolades!

reviewText: After watching and falling in love with series one of Wallander on Amazon's Instant Video, I quickly watched episodes 1 through 3 of series two of this engaging show.This series stars Kenneth Branagh as Kurt Wallander a Swedish detective inspector living and working in Ystad, Sweden. For Wallander nothing else in his life is more important than solving a crime. However, his ability to be great at his job costs him personally and you cannot help but feel for Branagh when you see how much these cases have affected him physically as well as emotionally.  I swear Branagh does more acting with his eyes then most other actors can do when using their entire bodies and it's impossible to look away when he is on the screen.Series two also stars, Sarah Smart as Anne-Britt Hoglund, Tom Hiddleston as Magnus Martinsson, Richard McCabe as Nyberg, Tom Beard as Svedberg, Sadie Shimmin as Lisa Holgersson, Jeany Spark as Linda Wallander (Kurt's daughter), David Warner as Povel Wallander (Kurt's father), and Saskia Reeves as Vanja Andersson.Filmed in 2010 series two consists of the following episodes:"Faceless Killers" Wallander investigates the murders of an elderly couple living in a remote part of the country.  Due to Wallander believing that one of the victims' dying words was "foreigners" when asked who attacked her it causes repercussions in Ystad with racial fighting between groups. Wallander gets to the bottom of who was behind the killings while trying to navigate the professional quagmire he is in.(5 stars)"The Man Who Smiled" Wallander still reeling from the events in "Faceless Killers" has been hiding away from his family and friends for months. When a friend contacts him with help trying to prove this father was murdered it leads Wallander back to Ystad and him trying to make amends with those who left behind. (5 stars)"The Fifth Woman" Wallander investigates when an old man falls to his death and it becomes apparent he was murdered. Another man is missing and quickly the two cases become entwined.  Wallander finds himself for the first time in years to begin to care for another woman. 4 starsI found episodes one and two so very good that I was very let down by the last episode, "The Fifth Woman". I think perhaps it was because at times Wallandar is such a contradiction. He wants to reach out to people but often turns them away and then acts surprised when people stop trying to get close to him. I really did love "Faceless Killers" and watching the fallout of those events impact him in "The Man Who Smiled." I did find series two to be much darker than series one if that is possible though I did love the end of the Fifth Woman since it seemed that finally there could be a happy ending for our dour detective in the future.Please note that I was able to view this entire series for free due to Amazon Instant Video.
summary: Just Gets Better and Better (4.5 Stars)

reviewText: Kenneth Branagh may be the most overlooked actor on TV. And Wallander is quickly becoming one of my favorite shows. Similar styles and feel to The Killings, yet set in Sweden of all places. Moving performances from the star and all the supporting cast members along with imaginative Sherlock Holmes style crimes will keep you guessing the crooks and their motives from beginning to end. Set in a gritty, yet stylistically appealing venue, this show delivers over and over again. Incredibly short seasons are a plus in this and prevents the show and it's characters from getting old and predictable. Well done guys!

reviewText: I have just read the 5 other reviews.  I don't understand the one review stating that a wonderful cast was wasted.  Another reviewer felt the series was depressing and so on.  Thankfully, in America, so far, everyone is entitled to their opinion, unless you are not politically correct.The cast is outstanding and we felt that both season 1 and 2 have been excellent.  For us, spell binding.  I cannot disagree that they are dark, but that is what they are and if that is not your thing don't watch them.  They are not Nanny McPhee. These stories are heavy.  We totally disagree that the characters are not well developed.  Each episode is approximately 90 minutes long and there are quite a number of characters.  How much can you do in 90 minutes?  There is no way to develop every character like a book can.  For those that can take some nasty, gruesome violence with some seedy characters, suspense and shot in a gloomy environment give this series a try.  We are not very good with violence, but the suspense and fabulous acting hooked us.

reviewText: This series is different than the original Swedish series, which I didn't watch because I don't like subtitles. This is the English version.  Wallender definitely has problems.  He is divorced with a father he doesn't see, a grown daughter who he wants to see but has no time.  His whole life is his work of solving crimes.  He drinks too much, is very brooding, and just has a lot of baggage he doesn't handle very well.  I have really enjoyed this series.  I don't know if it is still being made, but I hope so.

reviewText: Nyland (or is it Nyberg...?), after Kurt's dad died, funeral finished, the suitcase found. Everyone wants to go home but Kurt and the female detective invites Kurt to dinner a her place, Nyberg is coming, too. Nyberg (or is it Nyland?) says, "She does this fantastic boiled fish thing..." I could not stop laughing. That is this whole production in a nutshell. A boiled fish thing that is fantastic, as in, "unbelievable". I watch it because I have read the books (in Swedish) and enjoyed them, but this rendition suffers from the producers and directors having seen too many Bergman films, and exaggerating the human issues in Ingmar's oeuvre until they are caricatures of what British people think someone who is a Swede might be like. 3 stars for scenery.
summary: The line that sums it all up

reviewText: If you like really deep thinking detective mysteries, this is for you.  That said, you almost have to see the series from the VERY beginning (Season 1 - Episode 1), and follow it without fail.  The show is set in Sweden, but the dialogue is in English (British 'accents'), so when the characters name places (cities, lakes, etc.) they are all Swedish locations.  That can be confusing at first.  It seems that the main character in so many series lately has to be 'troubled' or have a dark past, and that affects his/her performance as a law officer.  Kurt Wallender is no exception.  His wife has died.  He has a daughter whom he rarely sees.  He relies on pills.  Etc. Etc. Etc.  All-in-all, the show has excellent acting.  And the scenery is spectacular.  Due to the fact there are a limited number of episodes, I space my viewing as I don't want it end.  I give it 2 thumbs up!
